resource.chars:
colour and transmitt those of another as they do 
according to the 13 & 15 Observac[i]ons. For it is not 
to be imagined, that at one place the rayes, wch  for instance 
exhibit a blew colour, Should haue the fortune to dash upon 
the <u>partes<\u>, & those wch exhibit a Red to hit upon th pores 
of the body, & then at another place where the body is 
either a little thicker, or a little thinner, that on the 
contrary the blew Should hitt upon its <u>pores<\u>, and the red 
upon its <u>parts<\u>.
Prop. 9th. Tis most probable, that the rayes which 
impinge on the Solid parts of any body, are not reflected 
but Stifled & lost in that body.
This is consentaneous to the precedent Proposition 
and will further appeare by considering, that if all the Rayes 
Should be reflected wch impinge on the internall parts of clear 
water or Crystall, those Substances Should rather haue 
a cloudy then so very clear transparency.
And further there would be no Principle of the Obscurity 
or blacknesse wch Some bodyes haue in all positions of the 
eye. For to produce this effect it is necessary that many ray[s]
be retained & lost in the body, & it seems not probable, that 
any rayes can be Stopt & retained in it wch do not impinge on 
its parts.
